instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC: What is SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC? SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC is a voltage that is created if SMC_BC_ACOK & PP3V42_G3H are both present that powers the chipset for the onewire circuit that allows the SMC to talk to the charger on the SYS_ONEWIRE line. This is necessary for the magsafe charger to have a light on it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light and ppbus 12.3
threads.message:
Hello 
Im working on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board and cant understand whats wrong with it. Have replaced SMC with no change. Some measurements 

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.43V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> .   12.3v
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> 2.84v
<SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> 2.85v

As always Im using genuine charger and tried known good dc in board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light and ppbus 12.3
threads.message:
solved it so far. Pad under <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> was gone replaced and now I have green and orange light and ppbus are 12.6 volts. 

Still no fan spin but one step closer

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light and ppbus 12.3
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> (supposed to be high) and check for reaction at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light and ppbus 12.3
threads.message: One more to the donor board pile. <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> short and CPU heats up
